## Natural history notes

The White Lobelia (Lobelia paludosa) is a perennial wetland wildflower. It typically grows in wet pine flatwoods, savannas, ditches, swamp edges, and dune swales. In Florida, it is considered endemic (or nearly so) and is assigned the wetland indicator status OBL (obligate wetland species) in the Atlantic & Gulf Coastal Plain region, meaning it almost always occurs in wetlands. The species epithet paludosa comes from Latin paludosus, meaning “boggy” or “swampy,” reflecting the plant’s preference for wet habitats.
